steps.title: Squat down on your toes.
steps.content: Squat down on your toes. From standing position, lower yourself down to a squatting position. Balance on your toes with your arms between your knees and your hands clasped. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Lower yourself down onto your knees.
steps.content: Lower yourself down onto your knees. Rest your knees on the ground, placing your hands and forearms extended straight in front of you. You will be a in position very similar to child’s pose. Spread your knees wide, while making sure that your big toes are touching. Rest your buttocks on your heels and place your forehead on the floor. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use your arms to build your foundation.
steps.content: Use your arms to build your foundation. Interlock your fingers and place your elbows shoulder-width apart on the mat. Make sure that your arms are horizontally out in front. [3] X Research source The elbows should be about one forearm’s length apart. This is roughly 30cm or 1ft. This gives you a sturdy base for when you raise your body , which we'll cover later.

steps.title: Position your hands to hold your head.
steps.content: Position your hands to hold your head. Create a bowl with your hands that will hold your head. Make sure that your fingers are comfortable and not getting squished. [4] X Research source Depending on which hand is on the bottom, the little or pinky finger can sometimes get in the way. You can either place it within the bowl made by your interlocked hands or slightly underneath it.

steps.title: Put your head in your hands.
steps.content: Put your head in your hands. Bend forward and place the top of your head on the ground and the back of your head between your palms. Be sure to check that your shoulders are not putting too much pressure on your head and neck. Test this by moving your head from side to side in your hands. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Straighten your legs.
steps.content: Straighten your legs. Extend both of your legs and raise your buttocks in the air. Keep your knees straight. [6] X Research source This movement is similar to that made during downward dog or dolphin pose. [7] X Research source You'll return to this pose later when you transition out of sirsasana . Be sure to warm up before trying this pose. If your hamstrings are tight, this movement will be very difficult to do.

steps.title: Walk your feet towards your hands.
steps.content: Walk your feet towards your hands. Slowly take small steps forward until the head, neck and back form a straight line and are perpendicular to the ground. Your upper body should be completely vertical. [8] X Research source Avoid looking into a mirror because this may cause you to lose your balance. If you are trying the pose for the first time, be sure to have an experienced practitioner of yoga there to help you. More advanced practitioners may be able to lift their legs straight up without walking them towards their head.

steps.title: Slowly lift your feet off the floor.
steps.content: Slowly lift your feet off the floor. One at a time, bend your knees and gradually lift your feet off the floor. Pull each knee in to your chest and keep your toes pointed up. We'll tell you how to reverse this position to release from the pose later. To maintain your balance, focus on pushing through your back and shoulders into the ground. [9] X Research source For more advanced practitioners, try straightening your legs out in front of you, instead of bending your knees to your chest.

steps.title: Stretch your legs upwards.
steps.content: Stretch your legs upwards. Slowly extend your legs towards the ceiling. Straighten your legs and keep your toes pointed. Maintain your balance by focusing on pushing through back, shoulders, and arms into the ground. [10] X Research source Focus on your breathing. Exhale once you have brought your knees to your chest and then straighten them towards the ceiling when you inhale.

steps.title: Lower the knees back down to the chest.
steps.content: Lower the knees back down to the chest. Once you have completed the position, gradually bring the knees back down to the chest. Bend at the hips until your knees are close to your chest. Continue to focus on your breathing and push into the ground for balance. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Place both feet on the floor.
steps.content: Place both feet on the floor. One at a time, lower your toes to the ground. Keep your knees and back straight. If needed, hold this position for a moment to balance yourself. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Return to your hands and knees.
steps.content: Return to your hands and knees. Bend the knees and lower your hips. Move towards the ground until your weight is on your legs. Bring your upper body down and rest your head on the ground. Stay in this pose for 15 to 30 seconds. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Roll back into sitting position.
steps.content: Roll back into sitting position. Lift your head and straighten your back. Slowly shift your weight forward onto your toes. One after the other, straighten your legs out into sitting position with your buttocks on the ground. Your back should still be straight and vertical with the ground. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Lower yourself into supine position.
steps.content: Lower yourself into supine position. Lean back and place your elbows on the ground. Gradually lower your upper body until your back is touching the ground. Extend your arms and legs a little, creating a comfortable and relaxing position. Close your eyes and focus on your breathing. [15] X Research source
